questions.text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine antenatal check-up at 28 weeks gestation. She has a history of obesity but no previous history of diabetes. Her fasting plasma glucose level is 104 mg/dL, and her 2-hour plasma glucose level after a 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is 167 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Start lifestyle modifications and repeat OGTT at 32 weeks gestation.
Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy.
Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.

Explanation:

According to WHO criteria, GDM is diagnosed if

Start lifestyle modifications and repeat OGTT at 32 weeks gestation (Option A): No need to repeat 

Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy (Option B): She does not have pre exisiting DM and insulin is not started at this levels of glucose 

Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline (Option D):Monitoring without intervention is inappropriate because the patient meets the criteria for GDM diagnosis and requires management to optimise maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, at 24 weeks of gestation, comes to the antenatal clinic for a regular checkup. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oral glucose tolerance test

Explanation:

The most appropriate test for diagnosis of gestational diabetes is the oral glucose tolerance test.

One-step approach recommended by WHO and IAD PSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group):

  • It is done in all pregnant females at 24-28 weeks.
  • It is used both for screening and diagnostic purposes.
  • The patient is advised to have an unrestricted diet for 72 hours, followed by overnight fasting, and then 75 gm of glucose is given.
  • A total of 3 samples are taken:
    • 1st sample: Fasting sample.
    • 2nd sample: After 1 hour of 75 gm of glucose.
    • 3rd sample: After 2 hours of 75 gm of glucose.
  • Interpretation: If any 1 value is abnormal, the patient is considered as having gestational diabetes.

mmol/litre

Fasting

≤ 92

5.1

1 hour

≤ 180

10.1

≤ 153

8.5

The two-step approach advocated by ACOG is not recommended due to its two-step process:

  • Oral glucose challenge test: Performed by giving 50 gm of glucose irrespective of previous meals and no fasting required.
  • Glucose tolerance test: Confirmatory test is done using 100 gm of glucose after overnight fasting of 8 hours.

Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) (Option A) measures blood glucose after an overnight fast; useful for screening for diabetes but not sufficient alone to diagnose GDM.

A random plasma glucose test (Option C) measures blood glucose at any time of the day; it is not specific enough to diagnose GDM, as glucose levels can vary widely.

HbA1c (glycated haemoglobin) (Option D) reflects average blood glucose over the past 2-3 months; useful for diagnosing pre-existing diabetes but not typically used for GDM diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine prenatal visit at 32 weeks gestation. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled with metformin. Despite following the dietary recommendations, she reports occasional difficulty managing her blood glucose levels. Which complication is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Macrosomia

Explanation:

Macrosomia, defined as fetal weight above the 90th percentile for gestational age, is highly associated with diabetes in pregnancy, particularly when maternal blood glucose levels are not well controlled.

Fetal macrosomia with birth weight >4 kg (>90th percentile) probably results from:

  • Maternal hyperglycemia → hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the fetal islets of Langerhans → increased secretion of fetal insulin → stimulates carbohydrate utilisation and accumulation of fat.
  • Insulin-like growth factors (IGF-I and II) are also involved in fetal growth and adiposity.
  • Elevating maternal free fatty acid (FFA) in diabetes leads to increased transfer to the fetus → acceleration of triglyceride synthesis → adiposity.

With good diabetic control, the incidence of macrosomia is markedly reduced.

This condition increases the risk of complications during delivery, such as

  • Shoulder dystocia (Fetal cause).
  • Cesarean delivery (Maternal cause)
    • Indication: Weight >4.5kg.

Complications of gestational diabetes mellitus:

Maternal

Fetal
  • Preterm labour.
  • Urinary tract infections and vulvovaginitis.
  • Increased incidence of preeclampsia.
  • Polyhydramnios.
  • Maternal distress.
  • Puerperal sepsis.
  • Lactation failure
  • PPH (post-partum hemorrhage)
  • Fetal hyperglycemia.
  • Macrosomia.
  • Polycythemia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Delayed lung maturity
  • NEC (necrotising enterocolitis)
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesimia
  • Overt Diabetes can lead to complications like IUD, IUGR, pre-eclampsia and ketoacidosis.

Oligohydramnios (Option A) – Can occur in pregnancies complicated by diabetes if vasculopathy is present. However, it is not the most likely maternal problem associated with a fetus that is significantly larger than average (macrosomia).

Fetal growth restriction (Option B) – May result from diabetes with vasculopathy, but it is not the most likely maternal issue linked to a macrosomic fetus (GDM).

Placental abruption (Option D) – A severe complication involving premature placental separation. Though possible in diabetic pregnancies due to vascular issues, it is less commonly linked to macrosomia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with known case of overt diabetes mellitus in her second trimester complains of persistent nausea and vomiting. She has poor glycemic control and these symptoms have worsened over the past few weeks. What pre-existing diabetic complication is most likely contributing to her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diabetic Neuropathy

Explanation:

Diabetic neuropathy during pregnancy can manifest as diabetic gastropathy. It involves damage to the nerves that control the stomach muscles, leading to delayed gastric emptying.

The patient experiences persistent nausea and vomiting. It is treated with metoclopramide and domperidone.

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option A) is characterised by neovascularisation, microaneurysms and blot haemorrhages, it can lead to vision loss.

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (Option B) is caused by reduced insulin, beta mimetic administration for tocolysis, and steroids for lung maturity. It presents with symptoms like excessive thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, and rapid breathing.

Diabetic Nephropathy (Option C) is detected when microalbuminuria is 30 to 300 mg/24 hr. Associated with pre-eclampsia, preterm labour, and fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with gestational diabetes(GDM) delivers a 5.1 kg baby boy at 39 weeks of gestation. The baby appears jittery and lethargic a few hours after birth. Which of the following neonatal complications is the most likely cause of the infant's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoglycemia.

Explanation:

The case of a mother with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and a 5.1 kg baby highlights macrosomia caused by GDM. Infants born to mothers with GDM are exposed to elevated maternal glucose levels in the womb, which triggers fetal hyperinsulinemia.

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) (Option B): Symptoms of heart murmur or signs of heart failure and respiratory distress will be there

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) (Option C): Symptoms of tachypnea, grunting, and nasal flaring will be there

Polycythemia (Option D): Plethoric presentation, pathological jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia will be there

questions.text: A 35 y/o with pre-existing diabetes presents to the labour ward at 38 weeks of gestation in labour. She has a history of poor glycemic control throughout her pregnancy. The baby presents with features of heart failure at 8 weeks of life. On examination, the baby is found to have pan systolic murmur. What is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers with pre-existing diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ventricular septal defect

Explanation:

Ventricular septal defect is the most common anomaly in infants of diabetic mothers. It is an abnormal opening in the septum between the heart's ventricles, allowing blood to pass from the left to the right side of the heart.
The other anomaly that has a direct correlation with babies of mothers with pre-existing diabetes is caudal regression syndrome.

Coarctation of the aorta (Option D) – Can occur in babies of diabetic mothers but does not have a direct correlation.

questions.text: A 30 y/o female came at 28 wks gestation with 75 gm OGTT report showing 2 hr postprandial (PP) blood glucose value of 170 mg/dl. She was started on dietary modification and exercise. She came for follow up after 2 wks, her FBS is 120 mg/dl & 2hr postprandial is 160 mg/dl.. What is the best treatment for her now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Insulin

Explanation:

Insulin is DOC in Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). 75gm 2 hr PP values > 140 suggest GDM, which is uncontrollable on a diet in the given scenario.

Insulin dose:

Continue dietary modification and exercise (Option A) is wrong because once dietary modification and exercise are started, the goals to be attained after 2 weeks are:

  • FBS: 70-95 mg/dL.
  • 1 hour post prandial: <140 mg/dL.
  • 2 hour post prandial: <120 mg/dL.
  • HbA1C: <6%.

This goal is not attained in the given scenario. So, insulin needs to be started.

Glibenclamide and Metformin (Option C&D) are the only oral hypoglycemic agents that can be given in gestational diabetes.

  • They do not cause any teratogenic effect.
  • But first line DOC in GDM is insulin.
  • Other oral hypoglycemic drugs are C/I in GDM.

questions.text: A 34 y/o G2P1 woman comes at 39 wks gestation and her blood sugar levels are well controlled on insulin. Induction of labor is planned for her. Which of the following is wrong statement regarding her management?

choices.text: If sugar levels <70 mg/dl give 5%dextrose at 100-150 ml/hr
If sugar levels >100 mg/dl give insulin at 1 - 1.25 units/hr
Give morning dose of insulin on day of induction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Give morning dose of insulin on day of induction

Explanation:

Morning dose of insulin is omitted on the day of induction.

Important points to remember on management of GDM mother during induction of labor:

  • Evening dose of insulin before the day of induction is administered.
  • The morning dose of insulin is omitted on the day of induction.
  • Start normal saline (NS) at 100 - 125 ml/hr (Option A).
  • If blood sugar levels <70 mg/dl give 5%dextrose at 100-150 ml/hr (Option B).
  • If blood sugar levels >100 mg/dl give insulin at 1 - 1.25 units/hr (Option C).
  • Ideally blood sugar levels maintained between 70-100 mg/dl.
  • Hourly monitoring of blood glucose is done.

questions.text: A 37 y/o primigravida with type II DM on insulin is seen in antenatal OPD. Which of the following is not routinely checked on her further visits to diagnose complications of diabetes in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D) Fetal Doppler

Explanation:

Fetal Doppler is not routinely done in diabetic pregnancies, it is done if the pregnancy is complicated with fetal growth restriction. However fetal growth scans are recommended.

Fundus examination (Option A) is done to check for diabetic retinopathy. It will have proliferative retinopathy with neovascularisation and microaneurysms.

Fetal Echo (Option B) is recommended between 22 - 24 weeks to detect fetal CVS anomalies with pregestational diabetes, especially if uncontrolled.

A 24-hour urinary protein test (Option C) is done to diagnose diabetic nephropathy. In diabetic nephropathy, creatinine clearance is reduced, or there is persistent proteinuria (≥300 mg/24 hours) during the first 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A G2P1 is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What is the appropriate gestational age at which her delivery is recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 39 wks

Explanation:

A GDM female well controlled on insulin/drugs is delivered at 39 weeks to 39 weeks + 6 days according to ACOG guidelines.

ACOG guidelines:

Case

Time of delivery

Well-controlled on diet

39 weeks to 40 weeks + 6 days

Well-controlled on insulin/drugs

39 weeks to 39 weeks + 6 days

Poorly controlled: Individualise
  • Delivery between 37 weeks & 38 weeks + 6 days may be justified.
  • Delivery between 34 weeks & 36 weeks + 6 days reserved for:
    • Failure of in-hospital glycemic control.
    • Abnormal fetal testing.
